page.title: 03LAND FEATURES-COSHESTON AREA
page.content: The land in this block has two ridges running from east to west.The rock under the surface of both ridges is old red sandstone .The southern ridge reaches a height of 70 metres at Mutton Hill and runs through the north of Pembroke.The more northerly ridge runs through Cosheston village and reaches a height of 59 metres.An inlet from the Cleddau River (Cosheston Pill) separates the ridges and the underlying rock between the ridges is carboniferous limestone. There are some old lime quarries near Lower Nash. The area is very pretty, mostly covered by rolling farmland, with some areas of woodland and many trees in the high hedgerows which border most of the lanes. Apart from farmhouses, the only houses in the area are in Cosheston and north Pembroke.
